data.title: My opinion on the future to dBase
data.text:
With no new information about dBase and months of unfulfilled promises

of some kind of announcement, materializes one is left ponder the future

of Visual dBase. On thing is clear the future of dbase looks

bleak indeed.

After the announcement in June 98 that dBase would be transferred to

Interbase, a transfer which has never taken place, neither Inprise nor

Interbase has ever made another announcement concerning dBase.

In the wake of recent shake up of Inprise into two concerns, Inprise and

Borland.com there has yet to be an announcement of the direction dBase.

In fact dbase is no longer on Inprise's list of products and while you

can find it on the site you will have to do some digging before it can

be located. On the list of product where it can be found it is the

very last item on the list, this position though could be a result of

the alphabetical sorting of the list, but I digress.

Is dbase being setup for a big fall?

Is the treatment of dbase by the power that be a message to dbase

users and supporters that we can do without you and that dbase is on the

soon to be extinct list and there is nothing you can do about it?

I think we deserve better than this. Thanks to team B for the great work

they are doing, I respect and appreciate all the help and energy you

have provided to countless dbase users, a special thanksto Alan and Ken

who have pretty much taught me all I know and love about dbase.

The promises though of an impending annoucement has lost it appeal. It

doesn't work any longer. There is a well known aphorism

" A promise is a comfort to a fool".

Inprise we are not a bunch of fools. Come clean with us. Tell

us now about the future of dbase.

Personally I am not waiting for such an annoucement, I may be wrong but

I don't believe there is one forthcoming. What I can see possibly

happening is an annoucement that dbase has died of natural causes (old

age) and that all users of dbase may upgrade to one of another of

Inprise/Borland/Interbase product at a reduced price.

I hope that I am wrong but I believe dBase is dead and Inprise is now

using team B to buy them time to come up with a strategy to allow them

to convert the majority of dBase users to some other of its product.

This is my two cents worth. Feel free to agree or disagree with my

opinions.

JamDown Dread

As much as I hate to agree in this position I have to say I totally agree

with what you wrote <g>. The writing has been on the wall for a long

time. Inprise seems like a company that is floundering and the way they

have been chopping and changing their strategies it seems they are in

their death throes.

Putting all their eggs in a Java basket could really hasten their demise

in my opinion. I don't think Java is living up to it's initial potential.

I know that if I go to my technical bookstore, maximum discounted Java

manuals are sitting in a pile like unwanted children.

IMO there is NO way that they can get rid of 20% of staff and leave any

resources for further development of VdB. Who ever would authorise this

would have to be mucho macho IMO and the current climate in Inprise would

suggest that mucho machoness would be very unwise. <g>

Anyhow they need a big kick in the rear end for starting this Interbase

BS and keeping us in the dark for six months. That should have been

cleared up one way or another ages ago even if they admitted that they

didn't have a clue what they were doing <g>.

I think the best that can happen is that someone outside takes VdB over

but once again I wouldn't hold my breath. Call me cynical but the last

six months have been farcical and falling for more rumours that VdB is

being resurrected by Inprise/Borland would be just silliness.

Just my opinion.

Regards,

Vic

In article <79656t$f9...@forums.borland.com>, jpma...@videotron.ca

says...

> At one time, 100,000 programmers were making dBase applications. There is

> billions of lines of old code waiting to be transformed into brand new

> Windows applications. Lets see the opportunities instead of complaining.

And the billions of lines of old code if it get's converted will no doubt

be converted using another language. I would suggest that these billions

of lines of code gets rewritten rather than converted. Have you seen how

easy it is to convert a process driven system to an event driven system.

Not too easy. The advantages of having dBase in the name is not that

great.

>

> And please, we should stop lamenting because we don't get an upgrade every

> six months. Since 1991, we had Windows 3.1, Windows'95 and Windows'98, each

> of them were plague with bugs (2000 to 3000 just for Win'95). At the same

> time, we had dBase 5.0, Visual dBase 5.5, VdB 5.6, VdB 7.0 and VdB 7.01. And

> between dBase IV and VdB 7, nothing less but a small revolution.

I would argue that some of the one's you quote above are/were fixes to

make the tool usuable. Anyhow let's concentrate on VdB7.01. It is NOT

COMPLETE doesn't matter what spin you try and put on it. It is a

potentially great tool but not the only great tool. And if this is how it

remains I don't really think it's that great either.

>

> Just CorelDraw is upgraded every 12 months. And their users are complaining

> that they should get an upgrade _less_ often. It is a strange World, isn't

> it?

I tell you what is strange. How long people will wait in silence without

one official peep from a company on where there development tools that

they rely for their livelyhood are going. Last June or whenever the big

announcement was made re Interbase it seemed like something would happen.

If it was predicated back then that there would not be ONE official word

and by January 99 things would even be more unclear than then, I'm sure

the majority would have said that they would walk. But instead here we

are advising each other to be patient and the 'sun will shine in our back

door some day'. Meanwhile a deafening silence from Inprise/Borland,

Interbase or whoever. I may be sensitive but I take it as an affront to

my intelligence to be left in the dark for so long. Go to the Delphi NGs

and the other Borland tools NGs right now and the Borland spin doctors

are falling over each other to put a positive spin on things and placate

the masses. Not one little peep on here on what may or may not happen. It

is to Borland's advantage to drag this out for as long as possible. As

long as no one makes a big noise they can still make some revenue and

possibly if they try and sell VdBase in the future it can be shown that

there is still a market.

>

> If I have the choice, I would rather see Inprise use their limited resources

> to make a better VdB than loosing their time talking about it.

Well that's great. I bet you anything you like that is Inprise's

preferred choice as well (Not having to lose time talking about it that

is <g>). My choice would be to be told what is going on if anything and

if no forseeable future move on.

I'm curious on how long the majority on these NGs will stick it out

without some official sense of direction on whether VdBase has some

future. Another month, three, six I don't know. Borland has really jumped

in on any negative feedback on other NGs but here I guess they don't have

to worry. Everyone is too civilised and calm <g>. These NGs might be used

to more advantage by kicking up some dust IMO instead of discussing

rumours every few weeks on the next big development that never get

official sanction. And stirring the pot has helped get some reaction on

the other NGs regardless of what people may think. It may be argued that

the responses may be just a lot of blah blah blah but it's still a lot

more than what we have here.

> Am I outrageous enough?

Minor league compared to Inprise management IMO.;-)

Regards,

Vic

In an e-mail posted from Argentina, Jose Fitanovitch from Argentina asked

me, 2 weeks ago, what I was thinking about the future of Visual dBase. Since

it is precisely the title of this thread, this is what I replied:

When dBase for Windows 5.0 was released, everybody agreed: it was an

extraordinary piece of technology, released too late. All other releases

since are based on this solid ground.

VdBase 7.x is a turning point. OODML is a radical departure from the

traditional dBase language. Inprise forced dBase programmers to take this

new road to bring us elsewere, to bring us on new grounds.

More precisely, they gave VdBase to Interbase with the goal to bring VdBase

on the ground Interbase is very good at: making computers from different

platforms, computers using different database softwares, speaking together.

We all know it: the Internet is a giant pot of gold. VdBase must become

_the_ data publishing software on the Internet. If you allow me to

speculate, I believe that the next version of VdB will be a clear step in

that direction. But not _the_ final step. Retroactively, all changes made

into version 7 will appear logical. (SQL, OODML, etc.). If someone wants to

bet on this, I am ready to travel anywhere to make excuses on my knees if I

am wrong. But if you loose, be prepared to come in Montréal offering your

excuses to me (our winters are very, very cold...).

Inprise is only a small warrior in a technological war. Their strengh is a

solid technology. Their luck is the mediocre technology in Access.

The future of VdB is us, programmers. If we roll up our sleeves and create

programs based of this solid technology, the future is bright. If we keep

complaining about how imperfect this World is, then VdB will be like Apple

before the return of Steve Jobs.



"Romain Strieff [TeamB]" wrote:

> I and 99.5% of the population consider COBOL dead since 20 years,

> nonetheless all my banks use it and hire cobol programmers. <G>

>

I'll agree with that and even though I consider Dbase to be dead that

doesn't mean I and other users still won't continue to use it. I just don't see

why Inprise would waste resources they don't have on a product that isn't

selling, regardless of how we may feel about it. Obviously Inprise feels the same

way since they have putting zero resources into Dbase for quite awhile now. Its

not about if Dbase is a good or bad product, it's about profit. Inprise like most

companies is in business to make money if they aren't making money on a product

line then they have to decide how to make it profitable or cut it. If Dbase was a

profitable item I doubt this thread would have ever been here, so the question is

"fix it or cut it". Based on Inprise's current situation I can't see them risking

more money to try to make it profitable.I understand the fact that Dbase

programmers may not like this decision but how many Dbase programmers do you

think would drop Dbase if they found another language that they could make more

money in. Just comparing the number of posts on these newgroups to two years ago

should tell you how many people already jumped ship.

> > Inprise would be

> > foolish to waste resources on Vdbase, I don't claim to have the figures but

> > how much money do you think they lost on Vdbase7.

> ---

> None, they gained million bucks every year, because dBasers buy dBase.

>

Although, I could believe Inprise sold a million dollars worth of Vdbase7

(hell 5000 upgrades at $200 per is a million). But I would have to see the

numbers to believe they made a million in profits on Vdbase7 in the last year,

and even then I still probably wouldn't believe it.

I don't believe anyone has ever lost a dime on any version of dBASE. It has

always been profitable - though certainly, with less (or no) marketing, less

profitable.

99% of the computer world has considered VdBASE to be dead because it has been

as silent as the dead. But that doesn't say anything about the technology that

underlies dBASE - much of which is mirrored in other "hot" products. JavaScript

was based, in large part, on dBASE, Java shares a very simililar

virtual-machine architecture. Visual dBASE has proved to be stunningly

effective on the Web... which could ensure a long and popular life for a

product that allows Web development along with interactive access to virtually

every kind of data in the world. No other language produces the tiny, blazingly

fast executables that dBASE does.

The bottom line is that there's still huge value sitting under the hood of

dBASE.

In my opinion, it needs:

1. To be cleaned up

2. To be performance-optimized

3. To be simplified in some areas

4. To get its message out: "here's what dBASE delivers better than anyone else"

5. To be supported into the future for a good comfort level for developers and

companies

6. To be open and straightforward with dBASE developers - and include them in

the future direction of the product.

Kick in these elements and there's not a reason in the world why an industry

hungry for fast, dependable, easy tools to develop the millions of Web and

Windows (and Linux) applications that will be required for the e-commerce and

e-business revolution won't jump at one of the best technologies in the world.

Ken Rinaman wrote:

> Just a small reality check here guys, 99% of the computer world has

> considered Vdbase to be dead for quite some time now. Inprise would be

> foolish to waste resources on Vdbase, I don't claim to have the figures but

> how much money do you think they lost on Vdbase7. Lets face it they can't

> give it away. For Inprise to spend time and money on a product that will be

> only bought by a small handful of loyal users is foolish. No matter how

> much those loyal users disagree.

--



Vic Wolyncevic wrote:

> As long as no one makes a big noise they can still make some

> revenue and possibly if they try and sell VdBase in the future

> it can be shown that there is still a market.

----------------------

Mr. Wolyncevic,

Based on what Mr. Katz published in this thread, we can say that VdB is

profitable. With no marketing, Inprise sells a large number of copies of

this software.

Will Inprise release an upgrade to VdB 7.01 or is VdB a dead end? The answer

is obvious. Inprise will offer an upgrade because it needs money. In this

business, if you don't sell software, you don't get money. Unless there is

suddenly an infatuation for VdB, the only way to sell more copies, is to

offer upgrades to your customer base. And it is easy to offer upgrades

because even if VdB is an outstanding piece of technology, there is still

room for amelioration.

OODML is a work in progress. The 7.01 upgrade gave us the rowset.findKey()

method. For this amelioration alone, this upgrade was indispensable. I

wouldn't be surprised to see Inprise offering us a _useful_ rowset.rowNo(),

a rowset.fields["nField"].sum() and .average(), in the near future.

And frankly, if Inprise would offer to its programmers, some extraordinary

new tools to help us publish data on the Internet, would you resist and say

no? Certainly not me. And certainly not the majority of us reading this NG.

The message I published earlier at 13:53 seems a little bit speculative at

first sight. But if you read the lines published one hour later by Alan

Katz:

> There's not a reason in the world why an industry hungry

> for fast, dependable, easy tools to develop the millions

> of Web and Windows applications that will be required

> for the e-commerce and e-business revolution won't

> jump at one of the best technologies in the world.

you will have a glimpse of what, I think, Inprise have in stock for us.



Peter give me a break,

Do you honestly really truely expect that anything we say on this forum

will make the slightest difference to the outcome at this stage .

I tell you what is worse on this forum than spelling out a few home

truths and surmising the future. The fact that many people have been led

around for so long on this NG expecting something positive by rumours

etc. and putting there arses on the line regarding VisualDbase all for

zilch.

Just saying that VdB is going to survive will not make it survive. The

rumours and empty promises regarding VdB have done more damage to the

users of VdB than any of what you call 'rants' have done.

If a product is in such a pathetic state that we have to go around saying

'sssshhh don't say anything bad or it might go away', I think it is time

to start looking at alternatives quite frankly.

Regards,

Vic

In addition to what Alan said. I would agree with you if you could point

me to another development tool which has:

* a run-time compiler

* a command window (available in the EXE as well)

* a dynamic object model

* a DML with field level morphing / auto-lookups etc.

Well?

> Well we are on the subject of other languages what is with the hatred of

> Pascal on these Dbase NGs. I am constantly reading posts about how bad Pascal

> is, why because it has semicolons?

I haven't seen much evidence of hatred of Pascal on these NGs. Do you

have any specific exmples? That being said there is always a little

ribbing that goes on between developers using different tools. It's

natural. But yes you caught us - it is the semicolons! ;)

> It's not that I am

> trying to push Pascal as the greatest language every written, I am just trying

> to figure out why Dbase users seem to despise it so much. Or are we looking at a

> jealousy thing? Inprise spends more resources on Delphi and Delphi is Pascal?

> Just a guess.

Well maybe. Inprise spends more resources on Delphi than on C++ or Java

as well. Does that make sence? Inprise seems to feel that any marketing

whatsoever of Visual dBASE hurts Delphi. Why do you think that is? I'll

tell you: Because Visual dBASE is a superior technology and the more

people who find that out, the more people who will dump Delphi. This is

very disturbing to a Pascal obsessed company like Inprise.

My 2 cents.

Robert Pirani wrote:

First of all, Robert, thank you for speaking up here; the participation

in these newsgroups of anyone from Inprise is very much appreciated.

But I really don't buy into the "legal mandate" argument. Statements

such as the following....

"We are currently negotiating with company Xyz for possible sale of our

Abc product"

"A team of developers is currently revising the product for an inline

release that we hope to release to the public in the Spring of 1999."

"The possible transfer of responsibility for product Abc to company Xyz

has been delayed, but the transfer is still under consideration and has

not been ruled out."

...would not expose Inprise to any legal liability whatsoever, as long

as the statements are true at the time they are announced. And please

don't say that you guys are keeping quiet to protect your stockholders -

I'm sure they don't want to be kept in the dark any more than we do.

If anything, it's unethical to *withhold* such statements.



Don't believe it Phil. Innovation is what what American's do best. I

suspect that the R&D you are talking about has to do with the materialist

terms of manufacturing, the US is still, by far, the most productive (in

Couldn't agree with you less :-)

I program in a number of languages (including some, like Clipper that have come and

gone).

And, IMHO, there are unique features to dBASE that are shared only by other

Xbase-derivative languages, such as an interactive real-time environment (I spent

two hours in the Command Window today testing out an extraordinarily difficult

looping construct with filters, ranges and the like that would have taken me five

times as long if I had to write and compile an application for each test I ran in

the CW), the VM and tiny executables that deliver blazingly fast CGI, one of the

most robust data object paradigms in the industry, a stunningly productive

user-interface (when it gets fixed), incredible back-end performance, native support

for almost every graphic standard known to humankind :-) and lots more unique

features that I miss every time I dabble in, or start to move projects to another

language out of frustration.

Plus, I find the OOP model in VdB superior to all the other OOP models (I'm partial

to the dynamic object model).

To be quite honest, I can't give it up. I'm hooked! :-)

And, perhaps more important, many of us have a long-term investment in our

knowledgebase and object libraries and legacy code that we'd be loathe to give up.

And as far as I can see at the moment, I don't think any of us will have to give it

up.

So, before you cry "doom and gloom" and "everyone should switch to Delphi or

DataFlex" (DataFlex - are they still around? Worked with their first Windows version

and it was an extraordinary dog, IMHO :-)

Everyone should just chill out for a few more days and let's see what happens. I've

never misled the dBASE community as a member of TeamB or as editor of the Web

magazine. I promise you, I wouldn't be posting "false hope" at this late date and

risking my hard-earned reputation.

Potentially terrific things are happening behind the scenes. We'll just have to hang

in a little bit longer to see if they come to fruition. And we can all hope they

will.....
